long_desc.thetext: We need to write unit tests for the icon cache. We've broken it and fixed it a couple times recently. Trac ticket id: 2138 Owner: wguaraldi Reporter: nassar Keywords: UnitTest
Moving lots of cleanup-related bugs to the 6.1 milestone.

Good question. Here's what I can think of:
- Downloading icons - That we limit the number of simultaneous downloads to RUNNING_MAX - HTTP errors while downloading - Supporting etag and last-modified

There's an iconcachetest module with two tests in it. The first is for testing whether iconcache gets removed when another DDBObject is removed. The second is for testing the case where an item is removed before the iconcache has been created.
Ben: You know more about the iconcache than I do. What other things should we be testing?

This is a bitesized task for a new contributor or someone looking for something to do.
Documentation on unit tests is located in the wiki at:
https://develop.participatoryculture.org/trac/democracy/wiki/UnitTesting
Any status or thoughts should be in the comments on this bug.
Testing related issue--deferring it to the future.
Original author: wguaraldi
Original author: jed
Let's do this for 0.9. Original author: ben
Yeah, we need to fix this. Trac ticket id: 2283 Owner: wguaraldi Reporter: nassar Keywords: UnitTest
Not sure how this one got lost in the shuffle. I'm going to review the patch for 6.0. If it requires work then we should probably push to 6.1.

Created attachment 4158 Tentative patch for this bug
What would a proper test for bug #2191 be? Simply add the test data in comment #2, it's expected output and update the test infrastructure?
If so, the attached patch does (or tries to do) it.

This is a bitesized bug and could be done by a new contributor or someone looking for something to do.
Documentation on the unit test system is available in the wiki at:
https://develop.participatoryculture.org/trac/democracy/wiki/UnitTesting
Any thoughts or status will be in the comments on this bug.
Original author: wguaraldi
Original author: jed
Original author: clahey

Stay Tuned to oozeTV for a stunning up-to-date expose on the fall out from this and subsequent protests! Tue, 14 Mar 2006 16:55:00 -0800 Freeze Out â€“ Trailer http://ooze.com/bm/detail/1/19f2e84a3192369c5a0860ffe8f7a5248c224c16 19f2e84a3192369c5a0860ffe8f7a5248c224c16Freeze Out is a comedy about one man's ridiculous and overzealous attempt to get revenge for the constant ribbing of his best friends at his weekly poker game. John's weekly poker game is a sanctuary from the horrors of living and working in Los Angeles: a ritual of jokes, beer drinking, talking movies, politics, and sex. In short, it's a good time and the max bet is 25 cents so no one is going to go broke. But something is bugging John. His friends don't respect him; any chance they get they cut him down, tell him he's boring, make him feel small. He's tired of being the butt of their jokes and he's not going to take it anymore. So he raises the stakes, trains in secret and engineers a winner-take-all Freeze Out, never realizing it might cost him his 7 best friends. What starts as an innocent night of low stakes poker becomes a ripping lampoon of friendship and a funny look at how we all lie to ourselves. See how the MPAA controls what you see in this series of semi-animated films. Ooze was invited to create Proof of Concept visuals for a segment in the Sundance Festival film, "This Film is Not Yet Rated" - This footage, although sometimes similar, DOES NOT APPEAR in the film. These movies are more like a slide show that was used by the producer to show how animations would work in the final film.- They're still FUNNY Mon, 13 Feb 2006 19:46:00 -0800 The MPAA Mass Appeals Board http://ooze.com/bm/detail/1/a4e9475c06ba4c99eb2abf4c1a4600428d41785f a4e9475c06ba4c99eb2abf4c1a4600428d41785f visit Ooze or just Donate]]> Budding filmmakers learn what it's like to appeal a rating from the MPAA - and it's not fun. See how the MPAA controls what you see, in this series of semi-animated films. Ooze was invited to create Proof of Concept visuals for a segment in the Sundance Festival film, "This Film is Not Yet Rated" - This footage, although sometimes similar, DOES NOT APPEAR in the film. These movies are more like a slide show that was used by the producer to show how animations would work in the final film.- They're still FUNNY. Mon, 13 Feb 2006 19:42:00 -0800 How Does the MPAA Rate Films? http://ooze.com/bm/detail/1/e3fa69f4f1d490ba72ec50cc16886f8d93425bb8 e3fa69f4f1d490ba72ec50cc16886f8d93425bb8 visit Ooze or just Donate]]> How does the MPAA decide what movies get which rating? Turns out, it's a pretty arbitrary system with very little oversight nor any clear guidelines for filmmakers. In this "animated" video, we attempt to decode the confusing criteria the uses to determine the ratings. Ooze was invited to create Proof of Concept visuals for a segment in the Sundance Festival film, "This Film is Not Yet Rated" - This footage, although sometimes similar, DOES NOT APPEAR in the film. These movies are more like a slide show that was used by the producer to show how animations would work in the final film.- They're still FUNNY. What do we want? Porn in mainstream movie theatres! Why can't adults see people having raunchy sex in the comfort of a modern cineplex with its stadium seating, fresh popcorn, huge screens and digital surround sound? Ooze confronts confused patrons outside several suburban movie palaces, and is even "removed" by the LA County Sheriff's Department. Also includes an "artistic" porno we'd like to see in movie theatres called, "Traffuck." bug.short_desc: add unittest for very slow scraping

long_desc.thetext:
RC2, OSX:
if you add this webpage as a channel:
http://www.apple.com/trailers
Democracy starts beachballing after 1 or 2 minutes... and gives errors like this in console:
DTV: Stopping system activity updater timer WARNING: Calling <function callback at 0xd9baa30> on HTTPClient: http://www.apple.com/trailers/universal/miamivice/hd/ too slow (0.683 secs) Trac ticket id: 2374 Owner: wguaraldi Reporter: npr Keywords: UnitTest
Moving these from "weekly build" to "nightly build" version. "nightly build" should be a catch-all for anything build that shows up on the nightlies page.

This is a bitesized task for a new contributor or someone looking for something to do.
Documentation on unit tests is located in the wiki at:
https://develop.participatoryculture.org/trac/democracy/wiki/UnitTesting
Any status or thoughts should be in the comments on this bug.
Original author: wguaraldi

Original author: clahey
Fixed, but we still need to add a unittest for this Original author: nassar
Are we sure this only happens on OS X ? I'm pretty sure it could happen on other platforms as well because it seems to be a regexp matching problem. Original author: luc

attachment.desc: Sample code and data reproducing the freeze. Original author: luc

bug.short_desc: [Patch included] Open file dialog should list supported extensions

long_desc.thetext: The Open dialog should have the files of type pulldown menu populated with supported video formats. Trac ticket id: 4763 Owner: ben Reporter: jdragojevic@twcny.rr.com Keywords: Open file

(In reply to comment #9) > Janet, can you give this a look over and make sure we're not losing any > functionality. One thing I noticed is that you can no longer open downloaded > subscription files with the open menu item, but I don't think that's important. > Maybe we should add a *.* filter just in case though.
On my system (GNU/Linux under Gnome 2) there is always a default "All files" option in the file type filter menu. Selecting this provides the "*.*" functionality Ben mentioned.
I'm going to leave this one open until I get the go-ahead from janet that things are okay. Assigning to her now.

4a17b97 implements this one.
Janet, can you give this a look over and make sure we're not losing any functionality. One thing I noticed is that you can no longer open downloaded subscription files with the open menu item, but I don't think that's important. Maybe we should add a *.* filter just in case though.

Hi, thanks for taking the time to make a patch for this.
For it to be included - it needs to go through the review process and you will need to sign a patch contributer form. ben@pculture handles this so I'm cc'ing him here.
Created attachment 4404 Patch to add file filters to "Open file" dialog.
I've attached a patch to add a filter with "All Media Files", "Video Files" and "Audio Files" options. This is done similarly to `frontends.widgets.application.import_choose_files`.

This is low priority so I'm bumping it down to P5. If it happens, it happens.
This is a good bitesized bug for someone if they want to tackle it.
Re-assigning to npr--needs decision making.
Bumping it to 2.0.

This is tricky for a couple reasons, one is that open file can handle a ton of different kinds of files: movie files, .miro files, torrent files. Each of those should really be a different option. However, then we have a difficult choice we either have the "all files" option selected by default, which wouldn't make a big difference, or we select one of those options (movie files?) and force the user to change the pulldown menu if they want to pick a different kind.
Also, we would have to add code to all 3 platforms which is kind of annoying.
What do you think about this bug npr?
I'm accepting this bug and putting it in 1.3. Let's either decide to drop it or implement it.
Original author: jed

attachment.desc: Patch to add file filters to "Open file" dialog.

bug.short_desc: uninstall should check if the app is running

long_desc.thetext:
On Windows -
I have done this myself and also I believe a few other users have done this as well. If you choose to uninstall the application while it is still running - not all of the files get deleted from the system (leftovers in Program Files\Participatory...\Miro\... and it can result in unexpected behavior on a re-install.
When selecting Miro -> Uninstall - the uninstaller should check if the application is running and prompt the user to shutdown - and refuse to continue until the app is shutdown. Trac ticket id: 8462 Owner: clahey Reporter: jed Keywords: install uninstall

Created attachment 3956 A suggested patch to fix the bug.
Following the "TestRunning" code in the .onInit, I've added a similar code in the un.onInit function (with the same name as used with "TestRunning" but preceded with the word Uninstall e.g. UninstallTestRunning).
Since there wasn't any code removed (only added code) so I didn't rename the function to Oldun.onInit and just added to the original un.onInit (or should it have been renamed??).
I've built a release and tested it on Windows Vista and Windows XP and it worked fine (i.e. If the user tried to uninstall the application while the application is running, then the uninstaller would pop-up a message and won't continue until the user shuts down the application).
I have no more machines with different Windows versions to carry further tests on.
This is likely still an issue, but easy to fix. There's already a TestRunning bit of code in the Miro.nsi file, but it only runs on installation.
*** Bug 9457 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

attachment.desc: A suggested patch to fix the bug.

long_desc.thetext: Using the -profile command line parameter specifies the profile directory, however it doesn't change the location of the SQLite database stored in %APPDATA% Trac ticket id: 8489 Owner: None Reporter: ryanmccue@cubegames.net Keywords:
*** Bug 9827 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Marking this as an enhancement.

I'm changing this bug to add support for portable apps.
In the last 3 years, we implemented support for U3, then ditched it. Since then, there's a bunch of lingering code in the codebase, but we haven't been doing any U3 testing. It's likely the case that we'd need to do some serious work to support portable apps.
I'm interested in doing that, but it's pretty low on my priority list and I haven't had time to get to it.
I'm going to make this a bitesized bug. I'd love to help someone else implement support for portable apps for Miro on Windows.
Can you elaborate on how it works exactly please?

recently code was added to make a u3 portable app - you should check it out.
Clahey - is our u3 work also applicable to portable apps?
This needs to be rectified as soon as possible, as it's the only thing blocking me from making a Portable version (see http://portableapps.com/)

User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.8.1.6) Gecko/20070725 Firefox/2.0.0.6 Build Identifier:
Include an option to have Miro start up minimized. Currently at windows vista I get miro running at full screen every time I start my machine. This option could be placed in the Options dialog box.
Reproducible:
Steps to Reproduce:
I'm unassigning myself from this one.
I'm bumping this to 4.1. I want to implement this on Windows and OSX at least. Then figure out the bits for OSX, too.

So, having a further look at this, it seems that on the Mac this isn't so easy after all in practical terms. The reason is the startup protocol is fragile, it relies on the window being actually shown to get stuff done. I tried to do all that without actually showing the window the first time and it's missing bits - but I guess at this stage of the dev cycle it's too late to gut it any further. This is a shame, but we can revisit earlier in the next dev cycle.

(In reply to comment #12) > Bringing over comment #3 from bug #9199: > > """ > FYI, "System Preferences / Accounts / Login Items". The left column is a > "Hide" checkbox. When checked, apps are supposed to launch in a hidden state, > as in Cmd-H -- present in dock, but no windows visible. > """ > > This portion is OSX-specific. > > The rest of this bug is platform-agnostic. Changing the platform to all. > > Also, I'll toss it in my queue of things to look into for 4.0.
The hidden bit sounds like something that'd be easy to do on the Mac - it's broken because we unconditionally show the window even if NSApp().isHidden() returns YES on startup.

Bringing over comment #3 from bug #9199:
""" FYI, "System Preferences / Accounts / Login Items". The left column is a "Hide" checkbox. When checked, apps are supposed to launch in a hidden state, as in Cmd-H -- present in dock, but no windows visible. """
This portion is OSX-specific.
The rest of this bug is platform-agnostic. Changing the platform to all.
Also, I'll toss it in my queue of things to look into for 4.0.
*** Bug 9199 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bumping this to the unassigned target.
If someone wants to implement this, that'd be great. Let me know. I'm making it a bite-sized bug.
*** Bug 12098 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Bumping this to 2.6 and grabbing it.
*** Bug 10168 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 11024 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
jana - just so you know - there is also a preference for it to not launch on startup. Not exactly what you want - but a workaround in the meantime.
Please make inclusion of this option a priority. The start behaviour in XP or Vista is very disruptive and in your face.
The hide thing does not work on my Mac 10.4.9
GTK/X11 to!
Mac users can already do this: in account preferences/login items, checkmark "hide."

bug.short_desc: Need to set limit on maximum disk space used by Miro, not just set limit by free space on disk (feature request)

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8.1.11) Gecko/20071127 (CK-IBM) Firefox/2.0.0.11 Build Identifier:
Miro fights with other applications on my system that automatically download media files (iPodder being one of them).
The problem is that if Miro gets started, then it will take up all my disk space until I have (say) 1GB left, as I have set it to limit downloads until there is 1GB free space. I set the same limit in my other applications. So now depending on which application gets started (Miro or the others), that app soaks up all my disk space until the others can't download.
What is needed is an additional checkbox in the Download Options that limits the amount of disk space that Miro is allowed to use (i.e. total amount of disk that Miro's files are taking up). This would work in combination with the "don't start a download unless it leaves more than X free disk space", so that if both are checked, then Miro would only download if there is more than a certain amount of free disk space, AND it had not used up more than its allowance of disk. That way, I can stop it filling up my disk, and allow other applications to work.
Miro should "play nice" with the other kids on the block instead of thinking it owns all the disk.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Run Miro and let it download stuff 2. 3. Actual Results: Miro fills my disk.
Expected Results: Feature request- N/A
This bug should be easy to fix in windows. mac might be a little harder but not too hard either

I'm putting this in the 4.1 milestone so that I look at it then. We're working hard on the 4.0 release for the next week and I just don't have time to work through this any more than I have already.
I'm really sorry about that.
Created attachment 3889 Patch that adds optional max-size limit for movies directory

Created attachment 3888 Patch that adds optional max-size limit for movies directory
Moved get_movies_directory_size to tv/lib/util.py
Sure, it is ok to send it that email address. I'll move the function to lib/utils.py now.

So, there are a couple of issues here.
First, this is a non-trivial change, so we need you to sign a copyright assignment form. Is it ok for me to send it to the email address you're using for your bugzilla account?
Second, everything in dl_daemon package is off limits to the other code. It's probably better to put get_movies_directory_size in tv/lib/utils.py and then refer to it from both the downloader and the regular code.
Otherwise I think this is ok. I'm kind of skimming it right now because we're pushing for a release candidate today and I've got a bunch of things on my plate.

Created attachment 3877 Patch that adds optional max-size limit for movies directory
I've added a patch that adds the required functionality, it is modeled on PRESERVE_DISK_SPACE, ie, I added two new Preferences and updated the available space label on the UI. Looking for some feedback on this.

Sorry for assigning the bug to myself without any comments anywhere. I am new to Miro and would like to contribute. I thought of starting off with this one. I'm still browsing the code and hopefully will come up with a solution soon.
Vivek

Hi Vivek! I noticed that you assigned this bug to yourself, but you didn't add a comment or anything, I haven't seen you on IRC that I know of, and you haven't sent anything to the develop list, so I'm not sure if you did this intentionally or by accident.
Are you planning to work on this bug? If so, what's your plan of attack?
Making this a bitesized bug for a contributor to implement.

attachment.desc: Patch that adds optional max-size limit for movies directory

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 6.0; Windows NT 5.1; SV1) ; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.30; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.648) Build Identifier:
It could be great to have a new GUI (Graphical User Interface) for use Miro from my living room, using my big screen. That mode should have a simple and readable elements and all should be available under remote/keyboard control (no mouse). Just something like Joost...
Reproducible:
Steps to Reproduce:

We don't have enough manpower to go implement Miro plugins in other applications, but I'm happy to help anyone who wants to do that work.
Pretty sure MythTV has a plugin already. I don't know if there are others.
Making this a bitesized bug.
Or maybe a miro plugin für elisa...
I agree that Miro needs a "living room" mode for those of us using it on a television. Anyone know if this is in the works?
...or like Elisa, in Ubuntu anyways. I'd also really like to see better integration of Miro into Ubuntu's Media centre, rumoured to be using Elisa.

bug.short_desc: Elisa Integration for a remote control TV based interface....

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en; rv:1.8.1.11) Gecko/20071204 Epiphany/2.20 Firefox/2.0.0.11 Build Identifier:
Elisa works very well with media when you have a remote and TV. It would be nice to have integration with it and have it able to play all this saved media in a nice way. For example, saving the screenshots in miro also work without redoing the work in elisa. The interface should show new and downloading content.
Reproducible:
Steps to Reproduce:

This is something that someone should implement in Elisa. I don't think it's something we're going to implement because we don't have enough manpower.
Marking this as bitesized in the hopes that someone decides to work on it.

bug.short_desc: EnhReq: UI enhancement to allow PodNova feed to be read

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1064 External service subscription list
ENHANCEMENT REQUEST: Allow for synchronizing subscriptions from a remote service
iPodder & Juice currently allow user to add an OPML.xml subscription feed from an external source to synchronize subscriptions from a remove service, in its Preferences...Feed Manager dialog box.
Ex: http://feeds.podnova.com/32a/32ad9389515551f0160810a2713333d6/opml.xml
This allows changing a subscription list in a single location that is then updated to any client that references that address.
A obvious and easy UI control in Miro to accomplish this same functionality would be greatly helpful.
Moving these from "weekly build" to "nightly build" version. "nightly build" should be a catch-all for anything build that shows up on the nightlies page.

I was talking with Chris Blizzard at Mozilla and he said that it's possible/likely we could use Weave for this.
http://labs.mozilla.com/featured-projects/#weave
Another possibility is to tie this into the channelguide where (some) people already have accounts and such.
Definitely a good bitesized project for a contributor to flesh out and work on. I'm marking this accordingly.

Yes essentially... This is current function of other products such as JUICE. One modification I would say is that the remote OPML would be checked when Miro communicates out to check for updates to the feeds. Changes in the remote OPML would then be reflected in the local feed subscriptions and the subscriptions then processed and checked for updates.

Just to clarify, Miro does allow you to import an OPML file and pick up channels, but I think the OPML file needs to be local.
So the enhancement request here is two fold:
1. handle remote OPML files accessible via http
2. check the remote OPML file every time Miro starts up
Is that correct?

User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Konqueror/4.2; Linux) KHTML/4.2.85 (like Gecko) Build Identifier:
With KDE 4 a new intermediate layer for audio and video was introduced which in theory should make it easier to create apps such as video players. Phonon takes care of the backend (Xine or Gstreamer on Linux) and provides cross-platform compatibility when used with the KDE base system on Windows or OS X.
While it will probably be a substantial amount of work it would greatly increase the integration of Miro into KDE. Especially in cases where users have several audio devices which have specific defined uses through Phonon which are not known to GTK/Gnome apps and others.
Reproducible:
Steps to Reproduce:
An introduction to Phonon: http://techbase.kde.org/Development/Tutorials/Phonon/Introduction
Someone's attempt at using Phonon in Python with PyQT4: http://pastebin.ca/1362335 Taken from here: http://www.mail-archive.com/pyqt@riverbankcomputing.com/msg16866.html
If anyone is interested in implementing a phonon backend and has questions, let me know. I can't work on this, but I can provide support for someone who is interested.
moving to wishlist.

I don't think it'd be too much work, but it's not something that I'm going to do. I currently have my hands full doing a mediocre job of maintaining the gstreamer and xine renderers. I don't think any of the core developers use KDE.
Generally speaking, the "renderers" are in platform/gtk-x11/plat/renderers/ . To add phonon support, you'd create a module called "phononrenderer.py" which implement an AudioRenderer class, a VideoRenderer class and a movie_data_program_info function. The gstreamerrenderer.py is probably a good example.
If someone wanted to take this on, I'm more than happy to help out. If phonon has Python bindings like gstreamer does, then it shouldn't be too difficult to implement.
I'd also be very interested in fixing the gtk-x11 code so that renderers could be provided as separate packages.
I'm going to mark this as bitesized since it's a well-defined project that's ideal for a contributor to help out with.

bug.short_desc: keyboard controls don't work with FC and gstreamer

long_desc.thetext:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux x86_64; en-US; rv:1.9.1.8) Gecko/20100216 Fedora/3.5.8-1.fc12 Firefox/3.5.8 Build Identifier:
when playback starts no keyboard controls work. In order to stop/pause/ff/rw/FullScreen/Separate_window video I have to click on control corresponding interface button. Keyboards shortcuts Ctrl+D/Space/Right/Left/Ctrl+F/Ctrl+T don't work. I always had the same problem on this machine on the 2.* branch using gstreamer, so I've been using xine as video engine (everything worked nicely there). In version 3.0 you left me no choice so I am reporting it.
Reproducible: Always
Steps to Reproduce: 1. start video playback 2. try to use any of keyboard shortcuts Ctrl+D/Space/Right/Left/Ctrl+F/Ctrl+T 3. no shortcuts work. Playback needs to be controlled by mouseclicks.
Expected Results: keyboard controlled playback
fedora 12. Fluxbox wm. Running from source build tree by run.sh
$ rpm -qa | grep gstreamer gstreamer-plugins-ugly-0.10.13-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-ffmpeg-0.10.9-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-0.10.28-2.fc12.i686 gstreamer-plugins-bad-nonfree-0.10.17-2.fc12.x86_64 PackageKit-gstreamer-plugin-0.5.7-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-base-0.10.28-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-python-0.10.16-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-bad-free-devel-0.10.18-1.fc12.x86_64 phonon-backend-gstreamer-4.3.80-5.fc12.i686 phonon-backend-gstreamer-4.3.80-5.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-good-devel-0.10.21-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-bad-0.10.17-4.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-base-devel-0.10.28-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-base-0.10.28-1.fc12.i686 gstreamer-plugins-good-0.10.21-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-devel-0.10.28-2.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-java-1.3-3.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-0.10.28-2.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-bad-free-extras-0.10.18-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-espeak-0.3.3-2.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-plugins-bad-free-0.10.18-1.fc12.x86_64 gstreamer-tools-0.10.28-2.fc12.x86_6

I can't reproduce this without building a new setup and I don't have time to do that. If someone else could get to this, that'd be great. Otherwise, it'll just hang out in limbo.
I'm making this a bitesized bug.

(In reply to comment #11)
forgot to add, just for the record. I tried to initiate a discussion on fluxbox maillist but nobody seems to be interested.

(In reply to comment #10) > Is this still a problem with Miro 3.5.1 and recent versions of gstreamer?
at the moment I'm at gstreamer-0.10.30-1.fc13.x86_64 and Miro-3.5-2.fc13.x86_64
I confirm -- the problem is still there. Keyboard control don't work as long as the mouse cursor is in playback area. They do work when the cursor is above the navigation bar in payback window. I thought the problem was specific to fluxbox and gstreamer, however after trying other gstreamer-based media players (like Totem) I cannot reproduce such problem there. Therefore it appears to be between Miro and fluxbox.
My workaround it to use external player for playback and it is nice to see you've added the option to Miro. However Miro cannot feed playlists to external players so I end up playing content directly from directories, using Miro solely as a content downloader.
Would be nice to see this fixed.
Is this still a problem with Miro 3.5.1 and recent versions of gstreamer?

I'm totally lost now. I switched to openbox just in order to enjoy videos in Miro. Now I have 90% of videos played as expected with working keyboard control, but there is that 10% which still separate the playback window from the main interface and controls don;t work. I just don't get it why this f**king gstreamer only works properly in that f**king gnome.

(In reply to comment #5)
> Maybe this has to do with fluxbox somehow?
I guess you are right, it must have something to do with fluxbox. I just tested Miro 3.0 in gnome, openbox and fluxbox under my user and clean test user. The keyboard controls work fine in first two, but don't work at all under fluxbox as long as mouse cursor is within gstreamer video playback area. I'm going to talk to fluxbox devs. Thanks for your help.

(In reply to comment #4) > How do you initiate video playback? Are you clicking on the playback button on > the bottom? Are you clicking on the play button for an item? Are you > selecting play from the menus? >
I always initiate a playback by mouse click on the play icon (or preview frame) on the video item itself. Since you asked, I tried all possible methods, namely: play button on the item, play button on the toolbar, "Play" in the playback menu and Play from context menu of the video item. All of those yield the same result -- keyboard controls don't work.
However, playing with all these options I found that keyboard controls in Miro work beautifully when I move the mouse away from video frame. In case of detached window I have to keep the mouse cursor on its titlebar in order for this to work. I assume this has to with the videosink for gstreamer. I checked it in gstreamer-properties and it has Autodetect set as its default output plugin, which tells me that it picks up X11. The only other options available are SDL, X Window system (no xv), X Window system (X11/XShm/Xv)
after playing with different options I can say that none of these makes a difference, except SDL. This one makes things even weirder, separating the playback window without controls off the main interface.
the default videosink for xine is set on xv, and this what worked for me in Miro 2.*. Besides that there is like other 10 options available in xine (including aa,fb and opengl). I don't see anything like that for gstreamer and have no idea how do I get myself more videosink plugins to test stuff.
What is your videosink? What are the other options you have for gstreamer?
I'm taking this out of the 3.1 target and putting it back in unassigned. It's not something I'm going to work on for the 3.1 timeframe.

Oh, whoops. I missed the fluxbox part. I don't run fluxbox, so I don't really know anything about it. I do know that Miro 3.0 works fine on Fedora 12 with the default setup (GNOME, Metacity, ...).
Maybe this has to do with fluxbox somehow?
How do you initiate video playback? Are you clicking on the playback button on the bottom? Are you clicking on the play button for an item? Are you selecting play from the menus?

(In reply to comment #2) > I'm not able to reproduce this. I suspect there's something missing in the > steps to reproduce, but I'm not sure what it would be. > > Can you elaborate on the steps to reproduce the problem? >
sure. What exactly do you want me to do?
my steps are:
1. start miro (run.sh) 2. initiate video playback 3. try to use keyboard shortcuts to control the playback -- nothing works
I emphasize -- apparently it is related to the video-engine in use on my system. It did not work with gstreamer in previous version either, but worked fine with xine. If I'm missing something -- I would be happy to find out what.

I'm not able to reproduce this. I suspect there's something missing in the steps to reproduce, but I'm not sure what it would be.
Can you elaborate on the steps to reproduce the problem?
Moving to the 3.1 milestone

bug.short_desc: Miro doesn't start minimized at startup

long_desc.thetext:
Hello,
I've got Miro from the Packman repository running on OpenSUSE 11.3 64-bit with KDE. In Miro's preferences I've enabled the system tray icon and told Miro to run automatically when I log in.
When I start my computer, Miro doesn't start automatically, so I used the KDE Autostart GUI to have it start at login. However, it always started maximized. Then I switched to using kstart, which is a program that allows you to start programs minimized, etc. In case someone knows kstart the command I use is: kstart --iconify --skiptaskbar --skippager miro
Miro still started maximized. Then I told KDE to not save Miro's status when I log off, so that Miro is theoretically closed when I log off and started fresh when I log on. Same result. I've also tried using the command ksystraycmd with identical results.
It would be really nice to launch Miro minimized at startup. Are there plans to include this functionality any time soon? Thanks!
Best, Daniel

Seems like you're trying to get Miro to start minimized by using KDE-specific things. Since Miro isn't a KDE app, KDE support is primarily done by community members. If you can figure out how to make the appropriate changes, then I'd be game for accepting patches. Otherwise it's unlikely anything will be done on this.
Marking this as an enhancement, targeting wishlist, and marking as bitesized.
Note: I'm pretty sure this is not a duplicate of the other "start as minimized" bug since this one involves KDE-specific mechanics.
